projectGridLines.stationName: Global Medical Education and Research Foundation (GMERF)
projectGridLines.title: Metagenomics analysis Title: Computational analysis of Gut Microbiome profiles in liver transplant donors and recipients
projectGridLines.description:
Metagenomics is a new approach to studying the composition of microorganisms found in a specific

environment using functional gene screening. This project focuses on identification of microbial

signatures in liver transplant (LT) recipients and donors using computational and statistical analysis of

bacterial profiles of 16S rRNA sequencing with Bioinformatics tools and by using QIIME 2 advanced

software. Alpha and Beta diversity indices assess the bacterial composition at various taxonomic

levels such as Phylum, Class, Order, Genus, and Species.

Computational screening helps us understand the variations in the intestinal microbial signatures of

LT recipients and, is recognized as an early target for therapeutic intervention during the post-LT

period. The methodology involves a series of steps such as cleaning the FASTq raw sequence data files,

removing first the overlapping sequences, and then chimeras, followed by clustering of quality filtered

unique sequences, and finally sorting them into taxonomic classification using operational taxonomic

units (OTUs) analysis pipeline. Handling the online Bioinformatics pipelines in this project benefits the

students to adopt dexterous usage of the metagenomics pipeline in identifying gut microbiome

signatures among LT patients.

projectGridLines.stationName: Global Medical Education and Research Foundation (GMERF)
projectGridLines.title: Development of Microfluidic Device (MFD): Title: Design and Fabrication of a Microfluidic Device for Biomedical Applications
projectGridLines.description:
Project Overview: This project involves designing, and fabricating a microfluidic device for biomedical

applications, utilizing CAD software for design and soft lithography techniques with materials like

PDMS for construction. The device's performance will be tested through flow tests. Required skills

include proficiency in CAD software, microfabrication techniques, and microscopy, along with, basic

laboratory and analytical skills. Effective communication, teamwork, and time management are also

essential. By the project's end, students will have hands-on experience in microfluidic device

fabrication and testing, equipping them with skills relevant to biomedical engineering.

Project Deliverables:

? A fully functional microfluidic device prototype.

? A comprehensive report detailing the design process, fabrication methods, testing procedures

and results.

? A presentation summarizing the project’s objectives, methodology, findings, and potential

applications.

projectGridLines.stationName: Global Medical Education and Research Foundation (GMERF)
projectGridLines.title: Genetic association studies (GAS):Title: Role of DNA markers in identifying the association with disease pathogenesis
projectGridLines.description:
Genome studies enable the discovery, and characterisation of genetic mutations/variations associated

with a specific disease. Currently, we are working on identifying the molecular signaling pathways

involved in the pathogenesis of diseases such as asthma, a chronic inflammatory lung disease;


Parkinson’s disease, a late-onset neurodegenerative disease; Premature Ovarian Failure, an infertility-

related reproductive disease; and Liver cirrhosis, a liver disease. Biomarker identification is carried out


using different techniques, such as DNA/RNA isolation, Agarose Gel Electrophoresis, PCR, PCR-RFLP,

and RT-PCR including primer designing.

Students will receive training on different hands-on molecular techniques, equipping them with the

skills required to independently manage tasks at bench-side.

projectGridLines.stationName: Global Medical Education and Research Foundation (GMERF)
projectGridLines.title: Identification of Sepsis Biomarkers Title: Identifying the Role of Molecular and Regulatory Cell Death Biomarkers in Sepsis Pathophysiology
projectGridLines.description:
Sepsis is a life-threatening organ dysfunction caused by dysregulated host response to

infection. The pathophysiology of sepsis is quite complex and involves multiple organ

systems. We train the students starting from DNA/RNA isolation, serum protein estimation

by ELISA, real-time PCR (RT-PCR), and the estimation of protein biomarkers by Western

Blotting techniques.

The project aims to (a) investigate the role of molecular biomarkers that are involved in the

cell death mechanisms signalling pathways such as apoptosis, necroptosis, pyroptosis, and

autophagy pathways in sepsis, (b) to establish the regulatory mechanisms (Regulatory T-cells)

governing sepsis-induced immune cell death, and (c) developing a multiple marker diagnostic

panel using microfluidics technology.
